content: <metadata><idinfo><citation><citeinfo><origin>Woolpert, Inc.</origin><title>Challis Valley LiDAR 2011</title><geoform>vector digital data</geoform><serinfo /><ftname Sync="TRUE">212_Challis_Valley</ftname><onlink>http://www.idaholidar.org/data/212</onlink><pubinfo><pubplace>Idaho</pubplace><publish>Idaho LiDAR Consortium</publish></pubinfo></citeinfo></citation><descript><abstract>This ArcGIS dataset includes reference contours, breakline and LiDAR derived mass-point features.  This terrain dataset is built from multiple data sources such as LiDAR mass point collections, 3D breaklines, and 3D-based survey observations. The data sources used to create terrain datasets are managed as a set of integrated feature classes in the geodatabase.</abstract><purpose>This project of work is for the data and photo acquisiton to enable mapping processing which shall include contour maps, and orthophotography covering the project area.</purpose><supplinf>CONTRACT:GS00F0038N  CONTRACTOR: Woolpert Inc.</supplinf><langdata Sync="TRUE">en</langdata></descript><timeperd><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>2011-01-11</caldate></sngdate></timeinfo><current>ground condition</current></timeperd><status><progress>Complete</progress><update>As needed</update></status><spdom><bounding><westbc>-122.634147</westbc><eastbc>-121.600004</eastbc><northbc>38.257941</northbc><southbc>37.114826</southbc></bounding><lboundng><leftbc Sync="TRUE">721860.622715</leftbc><rightbc Sync="TRUE">726618.986831</rightbc><bottombc Sync="TRUE">4927021.841825</bottombc><topbc Sync="TRUE">4946819.975339</topbc></lboundng></spdom><keywords><theme><themekt>Raster</themekt><themekey>contours</themekey><themekey>imagery</themekey><themekey>photography</themekey><themekey>LiDAR</themekey><themekey>lidar boundaries</themekey></theme><place><placekt>none</placekt><placekey>United States</placekey><placekey>USA</placekey></place><theme><themekt>ISO 19115 Topic Categories</themekt><themekey>elevation</themekey></theme><place><placekey>Idaho</placekey><placekey>ID</placekey></place><place><placekey>Challis</placekey><placekey>Challis Valley</placekey></place></keywords><accconst>none</accconst><useconst>none</useconst><ptcontac><cntinfo><cntaddr><addrtype>mailing address</addrtype><address>1150 N. Curtis Road, Ste 100</address><city>Boise</city><state>ID</state><postal>83706-1234</postal><country>USA</country><address>Denver Federal Center</address><address>Bldg 67, Rm 1070</address></cntaddr><cntperp><cntper>Lanie Paquin</cntper><cntorg>US Bureau of Reclamation</cntorg></cntperp><cntvoice>(208) 378-5166</cntvoice></cntinfo></ptcontac><secinfo><secsys>Unclassified</secsys><secclass>Unclassified</secclass><sechandl>Unclassified</sechandl></secinfo><natvform>Raster Dataset</natvform><native Sync="TRUE">Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.0.1770</native></idinfo><dataqual><attracc><attraccr>ASPRS Class II requirements for 2' interval contours, reported as .6' RMSE and 1.2' at 95% confidence level specified by NSSDA.</attraccr><qattracc><attraccv>1.20 feet RMSE</attraccv><attracce>The resulting map will have a 1.2-foot accuracay, utilizing X,Y.Z ground coordinates</attracce></qattracc></attracc><logic>Topologically clean</logic><complete>Topological and attribute accuracy was verified by visually examining the data in its final format</complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>ASPRS Class II</horizpar><qhorizpa><horizpav>2 International feet RMS</horizpav><horizpae>NSSDA at 95% confidence level</horizpae></qhorizpa></horizpa></posacc><lineage><srcinfo><srccite><citeinfo><origin>US Bureau of Reclamation</origin><pubdate>20110111</pubdate><pubtime>Unknown</pubtime><title>US Bureau of Reclamation</title><geoform>raster digital data</geoform></citeinfo></srccite><srcscale>100</srcscale><typesrc>disc</typesrc><srctime><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>20110929</caldate><time>unknown</time></sngdate></timeinfo><srccurr>ground condition</srccurr></srctime><srccontr>Orthoimagery</srccontr></srcinfo><procstep><procdesc>The LiDAR survey used a Leica ALS50 Phase II laser system.  For the Trinity River survey site, the sensor scan angle was \ufffd\ufffd15o from nadir  with a pulse rate designed to yield an average native density (number of pulses emitted by the laser system) of 6 points per square meter over terrestrial surfaces.  All survey areas were surveyed with an opposing flight line side-lap of 50% (100% overlap) to reduce laser shadowing and increase surface laser painting.  The Leica ALS50 Phase II system allows up to four range measurements (returns) per pulse, and all discernable laser returns were processed for the output dataset.To accurately solve for laser point and photo position (geographic coordinates x, y, z), the positional coordinates of the airborne sensor and the attitude of the aircraft were recorded continuously throughout the LiDAR collection mission.  Aircraft position was measured twice per second (2 Hz) by an onboard differential GPS unit.  Aircraft attitude was measured 200 times per second (200 Hz) as pitch, roll and yaw (heading) from an onboard inertial measurement unit (IMU).  To allow for post-processing correction and calibration, aircraft/sensor position and attitude data are indexed by GPS time.</procdesc><procdate>Unknown</procdate><proctime>1200</proctime><proccont><cntinfo><cntorgp><cntorg>Woolpert, Inc.</cntorg></cntorgp><cntaddr><addrtype>mailing and physical
